Resty operates a retail shop that she rents at the market. She has been in this business for the last 16 years, and she works seven days a week. Her major expenses include food and school fees.

Resty has requested a loan of 1,200,000 Ugandan shillings (UGX) from MCDT SACCO to buy boxes of soap, sugar, rice, cooking oil, beans and flour. Her major challenge includes transportation and seasonality. She is aspiring to build rental houses.

loans.use: to buy boxes of soap, sugar, rice, cooking oil, beans and flour

loans.name: Adolfina

texts.en:
Adolfina is a 45-year-old woman who is married to Benyamin, a 50-year-old man who is an entrepreneur. They are blessed with four children from the marriage, namely Desy, 22, a warehouse keeper in a building materials shop; Nevri, 20, who is still struggling to get a job; Martina, 17, who is in the second grade of vocational high school majoring in accounting, and; Marthen, 15, who is in the first grade of vocational high school.
 
Adolfina works hard to support her family. She has been running a piglets breeding business since 2007. Now she is breeding three pigs in three different cages and three piglets in a cage.
 
Currently, she wants to buy fodder, vitamins, and vaccines for the pigs. Her son, Marthen, also needs some money for his registration fees in vocational high school. Due to the lack of money, she has applied for an individual loan amounting to IDR 4,500,000 from TLM.

loans.use: to buy two more piglets to raise and more vegetables to resell.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia has been operating her retail store for 15 years. She is happily living with her husband. The couple has been blessed with two children. 

Lydia aims to have a stable source of income so she can improve her living conditions. With her strong determination to achieve it, she is asking for additional capital amounting to PHP 7,000. She will be using this loan amount to buy merchandise such as cooking oil, ingredients, eggs, soft drinks, breads, and canned goods to sell. She knows that having this amount of loan will enable her to have a profitable business. 

Lydia is looking forward to the approval of her requested loan amount.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise such as cooking oil, ingredients, eggs, soft drinks, breads, and canned goods to sell

loans.name: Cherie

texts.en:
This is Cherie, 28, a resident of Pontevedra, Capiz, Philippines. She is married to Erwin, a businessman, and they have children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. She and her husband are working hard to provide income for their everyday needs.

Cherie operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Anita earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 600 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 20,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory and also she will purchase additional items for her direct selling business. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Cherie hopes to improve her business and have other sources of income. She dreams to give her children a good and quality education. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Mkhitar

texts.en:
Mkhitar is 70 years old and he lives with his smaller son in Kapan city of Syunik region. He works now at the Kapan city utility service as a worker. Mkhitar has a vocational education, and for many years he also worked as a driver of an urban bus in Kapan city. After being retired from that work, Mkhitar became engaged in farming. His wife temporally lives abroad with their elder son’s family. 

So alone (sometimes with the help of his son), without hurrying, very properly and with great care, Mkhitar runs his farming. On his farm he has cows, calves, piglets and chickens. He works with several butcher shops of the city, and he provides them with his farm’s meat, both pork and beef.  Sometimes he also sells at the city wholesale market. 

Mkhitar asks a loan of 250.000 Armenian drams since he needs to buy fodder for his farm cattle, which he will store for the coming autumn months.

loans.use: to buy fodder for his farm cattle, which he will store for the coming autumn months

loans.name: Upendo Oysterbay Group

texts.en:
Rehema, who is in her late 30s, is married with two children who are still at school.  She has been running a business selling vegetables for three years now. She works from 6 am to 10 am daily and is able to make a small monthly profit.  

This will be Rehema's sixth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to buy manure, insecticides and vegetable seeds, and to pay the people who readied the farm for planting vegetable seeds. She has paid back all of her loans successfully. She used the profit to pay schools, build her small house and cover household expenses.  

Rehema will use this loan to buy manure and to buy different types of vegetables to plant and sell to more customers. She dreams of building a shop to sell food items.

Rehema will share this loan with her loan group "Upendo Oysterbay" which has eleven members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy manure and to buy different types of vegetables to plant and sell to more customers.

loans.name: Sri Sakthi Shg-Innambur Group

texts.en:
Ananthi is the featured borrower of the Sri Sakthi Self-Help Group (SHG). The local NGO “People’s Action for Transformation” (PAT) has been financing this group via microfinance loans for the last five years. With the loans, the borrowers have been able to improve their livelihood through the cultivation of crops. Through NGO training, the women in the group are empowered and have grown strong morally.    
                                                                                          
Ananthi lives in the rural village of Innambur in the Tanjore District of Tamil Nadu, India. She is married and the mother of two children. Her husband is a farmer by profession.

Ananthi, like other members of her group, is requesting a loan in order to purchase a smokeless stove for her family. The stove can use any type of solid biomass fuel including wood, cow dung and agricultural waste and is therefore highly sustainable. It also produces 70% less smoke while using 65% less fuel than traditional mud cook stoves. Not only will the stove help save money for each family, but it will also decrease overall air pollution in the village.

loans.use: to buy a smokeless stove.

loans.name: Heghine

texts.en:
Heghine lives in Dilijan city with her school-aged son. She is 29 years old. Heghine now lives in the flat of her relatives, who now are abroad, and she will stay here till they come back. 

Heghine alone has to work much and very hard in order to sustain her small family’s needs. During many years she worked at different restaurants as a waitress and now also she works as a waitress at the restaurant of a very famous hotel complex in their city. 

As she says, the flat where they now live is not furnished properly, and she hoped that she could make it more comfortable with her small savings that she has made through the years, but the money is far from being enough, and now she hopes for support from Kiva lenders.

Heghine asks a loan of 300,000 Armenian drams to order furniture for her hallway, and she would also like to do some repairing of sanitary ware in her bathroom.

loans.use: to order furniture for her hallway, and she would also like to do some repairing of sanitary ware in her bathroom.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay the university installments for this semester

loans.name: Unidos Al Futuro Group

texts.es: El grupo “UNIDOS AL FUTURO” esta conformada por socios decadas al comercio minorista y a prestar servicios. Norma tiene 33 años de edad es casada con 03 hijos dependientes. ella  presta servicios de mantenimiento domestico. El credito lo invertira en la compra de ventanas y vidrios para mejoror la infraestructura de su vivienda.   El grupo agradece a los inversionsitas KIVA por el credito brindado. norma es la quinta persona del lado izquierdo viste chompa negra y tiene a su hija en brazos.
texts.en: The “UNIDOS AL FUTURO” communal bank is composed of members who work in retail, and service businesses. Norma is 33 years old, married and has three dependent children. She offers house maintenance services. The loan will be invested in the purchase of windows and glass to improve the infrastructure of her house. The group is grateful to the lenders at Kiva for the loan. Norma is the fifth person from the left wearing the black sweater and she has her daughter in her arms.

loans.use: to buy windows and glass.

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica is a 51-year-old micro entrepreneur who resides in Pontevedra, Capiz, Philippines. She is married to Roberto, who has a vulcanizing shop. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses. 
 
Veronica operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 20,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory.

Veronica dreams that her business will grow bigger and hopes that her children will finish their education. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en:
Hello! Wilson is 44 years of age, a very dedicated farmer who does farming with a lot of passion. He is based in Sosiani, a remote village in Eldoret, which is home to the “crème de la crème” in athletics. He is happily married and is blessed with six lovely children. He is the breadwinner in his family since his wife does not work. He has been practicing mixed farming for the past six years and his primary source of income has been milk, eggs, crops and some personal business that he refers to as “side hustle.”

He passionately enjoys dairy farming and has nicknamed one of the cows “Chenuach” (from a person’s name). Dairy farming is a very profitable business venture in Sosiani village, and the growth rate is huge. Wilson has always wanted to increase his number of dairy cows but has been facing challenges of lack of funds. That is why he is seeking a loan to buy a dairy cow. 

With your financial aid, Wilson plans to buy a quality breed of cow that can produce between 10 and 20 litres of milk in a day. He wants to modernize his dairy farming so that he can reap more profits and hence improve living conditions. Through Juhudi Kilimo, an institution that supports small-scale farmers, he believes that his life will permanently change and he will provide nothing but the best to his family.

loans.use: To purchase a quality breed of dairy cow.

loans.name: Ance

texts.en:
Ance is a 28-year-old woman who is married to Alexander, a 30-year-old man. Ance and Alexander are vegetable farmers. From their marriage, they were blessed with two children, Arjunedi, 8, a second grade student of elementary school, and Maryenti, 3 years old.
 
Ance has two plots of land planted in vegetables such as mustard greens, string beans, eggplants, etc. It takes one to one and a half months to generate best crops. The crops are then sold to the vegetable trader.

Since she rents one plot of land, she then needs money to pay the landlord and to purchase more vegetable seeds and fertilizers. Therefore, she has applied for an individual loan from TLM amounting to IDR 3,000,000. The loan will be spent on land rent cost, vegetable seeds and fertilizers.

loans.use: to pay the land rent and buy the vegetable seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Kyauk Hle Bee Village

texts.en:
Located in Central Myanmar’s Yasagyo Township, this community currently has 5 village customers. This village is located in Myanmar's dry zone, where insufficient rainfall is very common. Most villagers are Buddhist and struggle finding access to affordable credit, as the state-owned agricultural bank is not active in the area. Additionally, the village has difficulty accessing fresh water because the land is covered with salt, which contaminates the water.

This new loan will enable the village to hire labor and pay for topsoil and the expenses of operating farming machinery. The daily cost of a laborer is $3, and day laborers are scarce because most of the young people in the village are migrating to other cities in search of economic opportunities. To supplement their incomes from harvesting crops such as sesame and beans, villagers will sell palm sugar, incense, and livestock.

Pictured above are the borrowers from the village: U Thein, U Tun, U Nyein, U Win, and U Kan. Included in the photo is U Kan (farthest to the right), who is 72-years-old and the father of five children. His main business is farming. His children have already graduated and now manage their own businesses. He used his previous loan to buy topsoil and hire labor to help with planting and harvesting. With his new loan, he will pay to rent a tractor and buy diesel for the machine that removes the leaves from his sesame plants, which are stored and fed to his cows.

loans.use: to hire laborers for the planting and harvesting seasons and pay for farm machinery.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy dozens of shoes to add to his current stock.

loans.name: Ghada And Omar Group

texts.en:
Hiyam is the featured borrower of the Ghada and Omar group. She got together with the other group members to acquire a loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua, because they have always been neighbors and friends, and they are working hard to develop their livelihood and businesses.
Hiyam is a 43-year-old married mother of two, who has been working to sell Tupperware from her house for the last fourteen years. She is a hard worker, who puts so much effort into developing her business, to help provide her beloved family with the necessary items to thrive.
She is acquiring a loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua, to increase her amount business merchandise with the newly released special summer collection.
Hiyam is the lady at the center of the picture, Suzan is on the left, and Rouba is on the right side of the picture.

loans.use: to increase her stock of merchandise with the newly released special summer collection.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to make repairs on his house.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy salon equipment.

loans.name: Antony

texts.en:
Antony is 31 years old. He is married to Judy and together they have been blessed with two children, 8 and 3 years old respectively. Judy provides additional income for the family.
Antony has a shop where he sells retail products. He has been in this business for the past 2 years now earning a monthly income of KSH 15,000. He has requested his second loan of KSH 45,000 which he will use to purchase additional products for his shop.
With the anticipated profits, Antony will be able to provide for his family and ensure their stability. His hope for the future is to be a landlord and to ensure the financial stability of his family.

loans.use: to purchase additional products for his shop.

loans.name: Benkelema 4 Group

texts.fr: Les membres du groupe BENKELEMA 4 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de  35 ans, 4 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles polygames à FOFO, commune de KOLONDIEBA,  une des préfectures de la  3ème région administrative du Mali. Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. Elles sont à leur premier prêt avec l’institution. La spéculation cultivée est le riz, l’arachide et le mais  avec KADIA N°1  1ère personne à gauche sur la photo position debout. Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter des intrants, la semence et payer les frais de labours pour exploiter 2 hectares. La production est vendue à KOLONDIEBA après la récolte à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 125 000f cfa qui  la permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en:
The members of the group BENKELEMA 4 are married women who average 35 years of age and 4 children each. They all live in polygamous families in the commune of FOFO, prefecture of KOLONDIEBA, in the 3rd administrative region of Mali. They joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to sustain their farming activities during the rainy season, and this is their first loan cycle with the MFI. 

KADIA no1 grows groundnuts, maize and rice. She is the member standing first from the left in the group photo. She will use her loan to buy inputs and seeds, and to pay for the plowing needed to maintain 2 hectares of farmland. 

After the harvest, the crops will be sold in Kolondieba to a clientele consisting of both men and women.  

Kadia expects to earn a profit of 125,000 FCFA, which she will use to repay her loan and to help her husband with daily expenses.

loans.use: to buy inputs and seeds, and to cover the cost of plowing for the agricultural season.

loans.name: Sabali  1 Group

texts.fr: Les membres du groupe SABALI 1 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de  40 ans, 4 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles polygames à DJAN, commune de KOLONDIEBA,  une des préfectures de la  3ème région administrative du Mali. Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. Elles sont à leur septième prêt avec l’institution, les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés. La spéculation cultivée est le riz, l’arachide et le mais  avec DIATOUDJAN 1ère personne à gauche sur la photo position debout. Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter des intrants, la semence et payer les frais de labours pour exploiter 2 hectares. La production est vendue à KOLONDIEBA après la récolte à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 150 000f cfa qui  la permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en: The members of the Sabali 1 group are married women averaging 40 years of age with four children. They all live in polygamous families in Djan, the township of Kolondieba, a prefecture in the third administrative Region of Mali. They collaborate with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution in order to better manage their agricultural activities during the winter season. They are on their seventh loan with Soro Yiriwaso, having duly reimbursed their previous loans. They grow rice, peanuts and corn, which is what Diatoudjan does, for example. She is the first one standing from the left in the photo. With her loan she plans to buy agricultural inputs [such as fertilizers] and seeds as well pay the cost of labor to work 2 ha [5 acres] of land. After harvesting, she sells her produce in Kolondieba to a mixed clientele. She plans to earn a revenue of 150,000 West African francs, which will allow her to pay off her loan and also help her husband with everyday expenses.

loans.use: to pay for agricultural inputs, seeds and the cost of labor for this agricultural cycle.

loans.name: Sinforosa

texts.es:
Sinforosa tiene 50 años de edad, es conviviente, vive en casa propia, junto a su esposo y su hijo. Ella cuenta con buenas referencias. Su familia es unida. Vive en una comunidad dedicada al comercio, agricultura y ganaderia.

Sinforosa se dedica a alquilar el servicio mototaxi, además se dedica a la crianza y venta de aves de corral y chivos, desde hace 20 años. Ella solicita préstamo para poder invertirlo en la compra de una nueva mototaxi para poder incrementar sus ingresos y asi generará mayores ganancias y una mejora de calidad de vida para su familia.
texts.en:
Sinforosa is 50 years old and lives in a common-law relationship in her own house together with her husband and son. She has good references. Her family is united. She lives in a community where people engage in commerce, agriculture and raising cattle.

Sinforosa works renting out motorcycle taxi services. She also raises and sells poultry and goats. She has been doing this for 20 years. She is requesting a loan to invest in the purchase of a new motorcycle taxi to be able to increase her income and generate more profits and a better quality of living for her family.

loans.use: to buy another motorcycle taxi.

loans.name: Oswaldo

texts.es:
Oswaldo tiene 43 años de edad, vive en el Distrito de Pucara, una comunidad de clima caluroso, es tranquila su población se dedican a la agricultura, comercio y ganadería, está ubicada en la Provincia de Jaén que pertenece a la Región Cajamarca, sierra norte del Perú.

Él se dedica a la compra y venta de granos tales como el maiz, cafè, menestras, etc; realizando esta actividad desde hace 04 años, Oswaldo ha solicitado un préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa de 2000 nuevos soles para la invertir en su actividad principal comprando la materia prima al por mayor para poder ofrecerlo a sus clientes al por menor y de esta manera generar mayores ingresos, mejorando sus ganancias y por ende su calidad de vida tambièn.
texts.en:
Oswaldo is 43 years old and lives in Pucara District which is located in Jaén Province which belongs to Cajamarca Region in the North Andes of Peru. The people here work in agriculture, commerce and raise livestock.

Oswaldo works buying and selling grains like corn, coffee, legumes etc. He has been doing this for four years. Oswaldo is requesting a loan from Edpyme Alternativa for 2000 PEN to invest in his activity buying raw material wholesale to offer to his clients retail and in this way generate more income, improving his profit and in the end his quality of living too.

loans.use: to buy raw material.

loans.name: José Armando

texts.es:
José de 64 años de edad, estudio hasta primer grado, sus padres no lo pusieron a estudiar debido a que no contaban con los recursos económicos y en lugar de eso mejor lo pusieron a trabajar para que les ayudara a tener ingresos en el hogar y de esta manera que les ayudara a sus hermanos menores a superarse académicamente.

José está casado vive en su casa junto a su esposa quien se dedica a los oficios del hogar, viven con ellos un hijo quien ya termino de estudiar bachillerato y es quien les ayuda a realizar los trabajos.

José se dedica a cultivar la tierra,  él siembra maíz y frijol para el consumo de su familia, también posee ganado que comercializa los lácteos que procesa de ellos, él se dedica a la agricultura desde que era un niño fueron sus padres quienes le enseñaron a realizar este tipo de trabajos,  él sale de su casa a las 5:00 am y regresa pasadas las 2:00 pm a pesar de su edad  siente que aún tiene las fuerzas necesarias para seguir trabajando junto a su hijo para llevar los granos a su casa, así como para seguir cuidando a su ganado.

El préstamo que esta solicitando a CREDICAMPO, es para comprar  2 novillas para producción de leche, ya que cuenta con un terreno fértil con buen pasto para el mantenimiento de ellas, teniendo el dinero en la mano podrá realizar la compra rápido.

Él quiere para su futuro construir una mejor infraestructura de su casa para vivir cómodamente con su familia, en un lugar digno para ellos y también desea tener una buena producción de granos básicos para tener seguro el sustento de su familia, siente que con la compra que está realizando podrá tener el lugar idóneo para cultivar hortalizas y cuando las venda con las ganancias que adquiera podrá ir realizando las mejoras a su casa, también desea que su hijo forme un hogar lleno de amor en el cual pueda el ver crecer a sus nietos y jugar con ellos así como enseñarles a trabajar muy duro para que ellos sepan cómo desempeñar un oficio cuando crezcan
texts.en:
Jose, who is 64 years old, only completed the 1st grade. His parents couldn't afford to send him to school, so they made him work to help bringing an income to the household. This way, he helped his younger siblings to improve in school. Jose is married, and he lives in his house with his wife, who is a housewife. Their son, who has finished High School, lives with them, and he is the one helping with the jobs. 

Jose cultivates the land. He grows corn and beans for his family's use. He also has livestock, and he sells the dairy products that he get from it. He is been a farmer since he was a little kid. His parents taught him to do this type of work.

He leaves his house at 5:00 a.m. and comes back after 2 p.m. Despite his age, he still feels he has the necessary strength to keep working with his son, to bring the grains to his home, and to take care of the animals.

The loan his requesting to CREDICAMPO is to buy two heifers to produce milk. His land is very fertile and he can raise them well because it has good grass. Once he has the money on his hands, he'll be able to make a quick purchase. He wants to build a better infrastructure for his house, to live comfortable with his family. He wants to offer them a modest place. He also wishes to have a good production of basic grains to feed his family.

He feels with this purchase he'll have the ideal place to grow vegetables, to sell them, and to improve his home with the profits.

He also wishes his son can have a home full of love, where he can see his grandchildren growing up, and he can play with them. He also wants to teach them to work hard so they'll know in the future how to do his job.

loans.use: to buy to heifers to get milk.

loans.name: Syengo

texts.en:
Syengo is a male Kiva borrower. He has five children, and he describes himself to be focused. 

Syengo operates a tailoring business where he makes clothes, and he has been involved in this business for eight years. His business is located in a highly populated area and his primary customers are individuals, schools, etc. He describes his biggest business challenge to be low capital. 

Syengo will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy tailoring machines. His business goal is to expand within five years. He hopes that in the future, he will expand his business and educate his children. This is his first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy tailoring machines

loans.name: Taung Ywar Thit Village

texts.en:
Located in Central Myanmar’s Yasagyo Township, this community currently has 30 village customers, including 6 CBO (Community Based Organization) committee members who help to lead the loan program in the area. This village is located in Myanmar's dry zone, where insufficient rainfall is very common. Most villagers are Buddhist and struggle finding access to affordable credit, as the state-owned agricultural bank is not active in the area.
The new loan will enable this community to raise livestock, which is a crucial supplement to crop income, given the variability of harvests in this region. One small goat costs $80 to purchase and can be sold for $150, a $70 profit, after nine or ten months. Raising livestock is also very helpful to farmers because animal manure is used as fertilizer to improve soil conditions, meaning that they do not have to pay for expensive chemical fertilizers. Additionally, many villagers will cultivate toddy palm trees to sell palm sugar, and many women will set up small grocery stores in their homes to generate supplementary income.
Pictured above are the committee members from the village CBO: U Chan, Daw Mi, Daw Nyunt, Daw Mar, U Phoe, and U Sann. Included in the photo (second from the right) is U Phoe, who is married and has four children. Two of his children are still studying at a monastery school in a nearby village. He is raising about 30 goats on his farm and will use his new loan to purchase more small goats.

loans.use: to help raise and sell livestock.

loans.name: Henzel

texts.ru:
Henzel lives in the village Srashen in Syunik region. Being very pleased of his first Kiva deal now he is impatient for his second one. Henzel is 59 years old and now he lives alone (unfortunately his wife died 2 year ago). Their single daughter is married and she lives with her family.  She tries to visit her father as often as it is possible since Henzel still does not get used of lonely life after the loss of his beloved wife. Henzel works a lot, all day long; he is the head of a rural village community and he himself has his own farm and a plot of land. In his farm he has cows, piglets and chickens. On his plot of land he cultivates vegetables and greens. The most beloved part of his garden for him is his win yard, which in September month becomes full of sweet and already ripe bear fruits of grape, the sort of which is the best, which calls kishmish. Henzel also grows crops, particularly wheat. All his farm goods he sells at the Kapan wholesale market through the re-sellers. 
Henzel asks this loan since he wants to buy seeds for crops that he needs for coming autumn sowing activities.
texts.en:
Henzel lives in the village Srashen in the Syunik region. Being very pleased with the help from his first Kiva deal, he is now impatient for his second one. Henzel is 59 years old and lives alone (unfortunately his wife died 2 years ago). Their only daughter is married and she lives with her family. She tries to visit her father as often as it is possible since Henzel still has not gotten used to the lonely life after the loss of his beloved wife. Henzel works a lot, all day long. He is the head of a rural village community and he himself has his own farm and a plot of land. On his farm he has cows, piglets and chickens. On his plot of land he cultivates vegetables and greens. The most beloved part of his garden for him is his vineyard, which in September becomes full of sweet and ripe grapes. The variety he likes best is called Kishmish. Henzel also grows crops, in particular wheat. All his farm goods he sells at the Kapan wholesale market through the re-sellers there.
Henzel asks for this loan to buy seeds for crops that he needs for the upcoming autumn sowing activities.

loans.use: to buy seeds for crops that he needs for the upcoming autumn sowing activities.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy more varieties of fruit trees to plant.

loans.name: Fatat Group

texts.en:
Tharwat is the featured borrower of the Fatat group. She joined together with the other group members to acquire a loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua, because they have always been neighbors and friends, and they are working hard to develop their livelihood and business.
Tharwat is a 41-year-old married mother of three, who has been working to sell Tupperware from her house for the last two years ago. She is a hard worker, who puts so much effort into developing her business, which will provide her beloved family with their necessities. She is acquiring a loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua, to increase her stock of business merchandise with the newly released special summer collection.
Tharwat is the lady at the far right side of the picture, Fatat is at the center, and Diana is on the left side of the picture.

loans.use: to increase her stock of business merchandise with the newly released special summer collection.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy soft drinks, energy drinks, beers, etc. in order to add to his shop

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy palm-oil, onions, margi, etc. in wholesale to add to her current stock.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy raw materials for his aluminum workshop.

loans.name: Henrik

texts.ru:
Henrik lives in Kapan city of Syunik region and he is of 57 years old. Henrik thanks Kiva and Nor Horizon for his first successful deal and profitable loan, and hopes for second one. Henrik is married and he has a daughter, who is married and she lives separately, and a son who lives with his parents. Henrik’s wife works as a cook at the restaurant. Henrik already 38 years works as a shoemaker. In his own booth near his house he works without holidays. He both repairs and takes orders of making shoes. Henrik works with pleasure and now his son also is interested in this craft and all day long he is near his father; he wants to know all the secrets and skills of this work. Henrik says that his customers are very happy to see that his son will continue his father’s work, and they say they hope that he would do it as cutely and with the same quality as his father is doing now. 
Henrik asks this loan since he wants to buy raw materials for his work, since with the change of each season he must have the materials which suit to the season and especially to the weather.
texts.en:
Henrik lives in the city of Kapan in the Syunik region, and he is 57 years old. Henrik thanks Kiva and Nor Horizon for his first successful deal and profitable loan, and hopes for second one. Henrik is married. He has a daughter who is married and lives separately, and a son who lives with his parents. Henrik’s wife works as a cook at the restaurant. 

Henrik has been working as a shoemaker for 38 years. In his own booth near his house, he works without holidays. He both repairs and takes orders for making shoes. Henrik works with pleasure, and now his son is also interested in this craft. All day long he is near his father; he wants to know all the secrets and skills of this work. Henrik says that his customers are very happy to see that his son will continue his father’s work, and they say they hope that he will do it as cutely and with the same quality as his father is doing now. 

Henrik asks this loan since he wants to buy raw materials for his work, since with the change of each season he must have the materials which suit the season and the weather.

loans.use: to buy raw materials for his work, since with the change of each season he must have the materials which suit the season

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a mobile phone and a solar charging set so that he may provide vital farming information to his community.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a mobile phone and a solar charging set so that she may provide vital farming information to her community.

loans.name: Samer

texts.en:
Samer is a 20-year-old Palestinian refugee, who has been working as an electrician for the last four years. He acquired vocational training to develop his skills.
Samer lives in a Palestinian camp, where his beloved mother took the responsibility of raising him after his father passed away. Thus, today he is working hard to develop his business to repay her, in part for the sacrifices she made to provide him with a good education.
Samer is acquiring a YOUTH loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua, to complete paying for building his house, where his mother can have a better living environment and make sure they can live safely.
He hopes that in the future he can continue to develop his business into construction and cover most of the services needed so that he won't only be specialized with electrical work.

loans.use: to complete paying for the building of his home.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a mobile phone and a solar charging set so that he may provide vital farming information to his community.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is a single mother of six children, two of whom go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. She has a business selling backcloth and has been in this business for 15 years. She has applied for a loan of 1,000,000 Uganda shillings (UGX) from MCDTSACCO to buy more rolls of backcloth. She generates additional income from selling cooking oil. 

Jane works in a shop six days out of every week and sells on wholesale. Her major business challenges include seasonality and thieves. She aspires to build her own house and also to educate her children up to university. She resides in a rented house and the family has access to electricitry and piped water. Her monthly expenses include rent and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more rolls of backcloth

loans.name: Confidence

texts.en:
Confidence is a 17-year-old entrepreneur from the Shurugwi District of Zimbabwe, who stays with her mother (standing next to her in the picture). She has been selling clothes for three months. During her spare time, Confidence volunteers as a community health activist, who disseminates health information in her community, and as a Camfed learner guide. 

With the requested loan, Confidence intends to buy more clothes and shoes at lower costs from wholesalers so that she can resell them at higher profit levels. With the additional profits, she plans to pay school fees for her siblings.

loans.use: to buy more clothes and shoes

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Hello world! Meet Judith, a single mother who is 36 years of age, very hardworking and a dedicated farmer. She is a mother of one, and she is based in Kona Mbaya, a remote village in the Kitale area of Kenya. This area is referred to as the breadbasket of Kenya because half the food Kenya consumes is from that region. 

Judith has spent the last six years of her life farming. She sells milk, maize and vegetables produced on her farm. She also offers transportation services to other farmers in Kona Mbaya village using her motorbike. Being a single mother, she has single-handedly provided for her child by engaging in seasonal business to make extra money. 

Of all the activities she involves herself in, dairy farming is close to her heart. She enjoys waking up every morning to go milk her cows and feed them with fodder that has high nutrient values. She is very close with her cows and has made a point in naming one of them Jessy. This is short form for Jersey, which is a very exotic breed of cow that produces high quality of milk. Judith has an expansive land and has planted so many trees which beautify the environment. She also has Napier grass that makes feeding easy for her dairy animals. 

Although this ever-smiling mother has been making profits through selling milk, she lacks funds to buy a good breed of dairy cow. She is kindly requesting a loan to buy a good breed of dairy cow and also to build a dairy unit. The excess space in her farm will be utilized properly once she acquires the dairy cow. The exotic dairy cow will produce between 15 and 20 litres of milk, and this will translate into more profits and income. Profits from milk selling will allow Judith to expand her business and start packaging milk and processing other milk products such as cream, yoghurt and cheese. In addition to milk, she will benefit from the organic manure from the cow, and she projects that she will be able to start a bio-gas plant in her farm which will save her money in fuel costs. With your loan, all that Judith dreams of is a secure future for her child.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow and construct a dairy unit

loans.name: G.s Los Coyotes#1 Group

texts.es:
La  joven Magdalena  es una persona honesta y responsable vive con  su madre  es  soltera vive en un municipio al sur de Honduras, su negocio es una pulpería.
Magdalena el préstamo lo necesita para la compra de pan, refrescos, azúcar, mantaca, huevos,  leña, maíz, café, frijoles, etc. con el préstamo espera  el aumento de las ventas debido a que contara con más  mercadería  que ofrecer a los clientes que la visitan y así cubrir sus necesidades.
Magdalena así mismo desea  que  mejore  su situación  económica y  se vea reflejado  con este préstamo. En unos años espera que  su negocio este posicionado como  un mini súper  y poder seguir apoyando a  su madre   ya  que  es  una  persona  de la  tercera edad.
Doña Berta Su negocio es la pulpería  desde hace 12 años en la misma comunidad 
Doña Ingris su negocio  es la  compra y venta  de  gallinas  y cerdos  desde hace 10  años.
Doña Adamiseb su negocio  es la  compra y venta  de  gallinas   desde hace 10  años.
Doña Lecia su negocio  es la  compra y venta  de  gallinas   desde hace 12  años.


Choluteca, Honduras – Julio del   2014
texts.en:
Magdalena is an honest and responsible young woman. She is single, and lives with her mother in a municipality in southern Honduras. Her business is a small general store.

Magdalena  needs the loan to purchase bread, soft drinks, sugar, lard, eggs, firewood, corn, coffee, beans, etc. With the loan she hopes to increase sales, due to the fact that she will have more merchandise to offer the customers who visit her store and meet their needs this way.

Magdalena  also wishes for her financial situation to improve and for it to be reflected through this loan. In a few years she hopes for her business to be positioned as a minimart and to be able to keep supporting her elderly mother.

Berta's  business is a small general store she has had for 12 years in the same community.
Ingris  has had a business buying and selling chickens and pigs for 10 years.
Adamiseb has had a business buying and selling chickens for 10 years.
Lecia  has had a business buying and selling chickens for 12 years.

Choluteca, Honduras – July 2014

loans.use: To buy bread, soft drinks, sugar, lard, eggs, firewood, corn, coffee, beans, etc.

loans.name: Luis Horacio

texts.es:
El señor Luis es un veterano de mil batallas vividas a lo largo de su vida, vive en el municipio de Santafé De Antioquia con su esposa.

El es un hombre muy trabajador y desde hace algún tiempo viene trabajando en el negocio de la preparación y venta de palomitas de maíz, prepara sus productos en un carro adecuado para esta labor y vende sus palomitas de forma ambulante a través de todo el municipio especialmente en colegios e iglesias.

Es un hombre amable y muy trabajador, siempre dispuesto a atender a sus clientes con una sonrisa.

Manifiesta que es un negocio sencillo de realizar para su edad.

El solicita un préstamo para realizar un mantenimiento correctivo a su carro de palomitas de maíz como pintura y arreglos en el motor.

El préstamo le dará la oportunidad de mejorar su negocio y de darle un impulso considerable a su actividad, permitiéndole obtener recursos para su supervivencia y la de su esposa.
texts.en:
Luis is a old man who has struggled through his life. He lives in the town of Santa Fe de Antioquia with his wife. He is a hard-working man, and he has been making and selling popcorn for awhile. He makes the popcorn in a popcorn popper, and he sells it in the streets of town, specially around schools and churches.

He is a nice hard-working man. He always serves his clients with a smile on his face. He states that this is an easy business for his age.

He is requesting the loan to do the maintenance work on his popcorn popper such as, painting and fixing the engine. This loan will allow him to improve his business, and to boost his occupation, allowing him to get the necessary resources to support him and his wife.

loans.use: to do the maintenance work on his popcorn popper to keep working and surviving.

loans.name: Sokkhuoch

texts.en: Sokkhuoch is a 21-year-old student at a university. She lives with her parents in Pursat Province, Cambodia. Because of the lack of financial support, she would like to request a loan to pay for her tuition fee. This loan will help her graduate. In the future, Sokkhuoch wants to find a good job and build a new house.

loans.use: to pay for her tuition fee.

loans.name: Discipline Group

texts.en:
These members are part of the group called Discipline. The group is composed of five members living in the same neighborhood. They sell vegetables, wooden chairs and tables, second-hand clothing, plantains and sewing accessories.  These women are reliable and have repaid all previous loans without issue. 

Rosemond, a star borrower, is the group representative. She is 45 years old and has married. She sells vegetables. She buys her merchandise at the main market in order to resell it at retail price in another market. She will use her GHS 2,000 portion of the total group loan to buy cabbage, carrots, lettuce and green peppers. She has been in this business for over nine years. She has a sales stand at her market. Her business is going well. She is known for selling quality products. With her revenues, she aims to help her husband cover household expenses and other expenses.

The group members will hold one another responsible for the repayment of the loan.

loans.use: To buy cabbage, carrots, lettuce and green peppers from the main market to sell at retail prices in another market.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a mobile phone and a solar charging set so that he may provide vital farming information to his community.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a mobile phone and a solar charging set so that he may provide vital farming information to his community.

loans.name: Sumomei Group

texts.en:
The loan group “Sumomie” is composed of six women who have been active for several years and have come together to benefit from financial support, enabling them to bolster their revenue-generating businesses. They sell cosmetics, cook food, cakes and lining.

Priscilla is the group’s representative. She is active in selling cosmetics. She has over two years of experience. The loan will be used to purchase more cosmetics to sell to customers. She is 26 years old, married and has one child. She moves from door to door and sells to her customers. With the profits from her sales, she supports her husband in covering household expenses and saves part with ID-Ghana. Her future plans include building her own house.

loans.use: to purchase more cosmetics to sell to customers.

loans.name: Bela

texts.en: Bela is a 51-year-old married woman from the village of Siktavra. She has only one 18-year-old son and the family earns a living with the help of agricultural activity. In particular, Bela takes care of milk-cow and pigs. She sells milk products locally, but the income is insignificant and they live under poverty. Bela requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for building a greenhouse, but without any success. Her loan request was rejected each time, because the creditors did not find the existing family income to be sufficient to approve the loan. Bela requested a loan from Credo to build a greenhouse and increase her family's income. Her loan request was approved in the framework of a new joint initiative by Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program provides start-up credit soft conditions for the country's rural poor, who, regarded as "high risk borrowers" because of their low income, do not have access to credit products. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva startup loan, will significantly increase the family's income and the family members will be able to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To build a greenhouse and increase her family's income

loans.name: Adalgiza

texts.es:
Adalgiza es una mujer de 44 años muy emprendedora y con muchas ganas de salir adelante y progresar.

Desde hace 5 años se viene dedicando a la venta de productos por catalogo como ropa, accesorios, artículos de belleza y elementos para el hogar, estos productos los vende principalmente a amigos, vecinos y familiares que conocen a Adalgiza y quieren que también progrese en su actividad.

Desde muy joven sintió gran afinidad con el comercio y las ventas, por lo que hoy en día tiene grandes habilidades en este campo gracias a su simpatía y excelente calidad de servicio.

Solicita un préstamo para comprar surtido de productos de belleza y ropa para aumentar su inventario y mejorar sus ventas, obteniendo así unos buenos ingresos para colaborar con los gastos de su hogar.

Tiene la esperanza de poder salir adelante gracias al apoyo de las personas de buen corazón que apoyan este tipo de proyectos.
texts.en:
Adalgiza is a 44 year old woman with an entrepreneurial spirit, who is eager to get ahead and succeed. For the past 5 years she has made a living selling products by catalog, including clothing, accessories, beauty products, and household items. The majority of her customers are her friends, neighbors, and relatives who know Adalgiza also want to her to succeed with her business. From a young age, she has felt a great affinity towards business and sales. This passion, along with her charm and high quality service, accounts for her great skills in this field today. 

She is requesting a loan to purchase an assortment of beauty products and clothing to increase her inventory and improve sales, thereby generating good income to help with household expenses. She hopes to get ahead with the support of the good-hearted people who support these types of projects.

loans.use: to purchase an assortment of merchandise, including beauty products, clothing, and accessories, to stock her business and improve her family's living conditions.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a mobile phone and a solar charging set so that he may provide vital farming information to his community.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase blankets, clothes and footwear for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy clothing and footwear for her retail business and feed for her poultry business.

loans.name: Liana

texts.en:
Liana is a 53-year-old married woman from the village of Guturi. She lives with her husband, who is extensively engaged in cultivating a plot of family-owned agricultural land, where maize and nuts are grown. The family earns income only from selling these farm products at the local market. They can't cover all daily costs with this income and need some investment capital to start any other activity. 

Liana has requested a loan several times, but without any success. At last, her application was approved through the joint initiative between Kiva and Credo. This start-up program gives rural poor people a chance to start their own businesses. With the requested money, Liana plans to start a local trading business with books. She will purchase the products at wholesale prices and will sell door-to-door at increased prices. 

She hopes that in the future, she will be capable of expanding her business to cover almost all of her customers' needs. Liana will be very grateful for the help and will highly appreciate it.

loans.use: To start trading in books and earn an income

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a mobile phone and a solar charging set so that he may provide vital farming information to his community.

loans.name: Zulfi

texts.en:
Zulfi is 56 years old, married and has two kids. For many years Zulfi has worked in farming, with his main crop being lemons. The work is going very well, because Zulfi has many years of experience and always worries about giving his customers the highest quality products. However, he has a problem with water because he has to get the water from his neighbor every time. For this reason he is asking for a loan of 1,200 AZN so that he can obtain a water pump to irrigate and expand his lemon crop.

Zulfi is very grateful to Kiva lenders because thanks to their support, he will be able to buy a water pump.

loans.use: to buy a water pump to irrgate his lemon crop

loans.name: Tolibjon

texts.ru:
Толибчон жизнерадостный и трудолюбивый мужчина в возрасте 38 лет. Он женат и имеет четверых детей. Вместе со своей семьёй Толибчон живёт в небольшой деревушке. Он очень любит свою жену и детей и старается делать всё, чтобы обеспечивать их всем необходимым.

Сам Толибчон по специальности является мастером по ремонту, он работает по своей специальности и получает доход от этой работу. Но так как это не постоянная работа, Толибчон решил заняться делом, которое будет приносить постоянный доход. Толибчон очень любит готовить и печь, а также и его жена умеет это делать очень вкусно. Поэтому они вместе решили открыть небольшое кафе возле одного из местных колледжей. Там они будут продавать пирожки и самбусу. Сейчас Толибчон хочет купить хорошую микроволновую печь для изготовления пирожков и самбусы. Поэтому он обратился в Арванд и хочет получить кредит на покупку микроволновой печи. Толибчон заранее благодарит Арванд за поддержку.
texts.en: Tolibjon is a house renovations masters by trade. He earns an income by exercising this trade. However, since he does not have work all the time, Tolibjon decided to launch a business that would bring him an ongoing income. Tolibjon really enjoys cooking and baking. His wife is also a great cook. This is why they have decide to open a small café near a local high school. They will be selling small pies and “sambusa” (a traditional samosa-type pastry). At present Tolibjon would like to be a high-quality microwave oven to prepare pies and sambusa. This is why he has applied to Arvand for a loan to buy a microwave oven. Tolibjon thanks Arvand for its support in advance.

loans.use: to buy a microwave.

loans.name: Tereze

texts.en: Tereze has changed her type of activity from retailing clothes to running an eatery. She sells mostly soft drinks, coffees and desserts/cookies that she makes herself, as well as fresh agricultural produce. The eatery is built at the side of a road in proximity to a village and a school. According to Tereze, sales have been increasing steadily, which she credits to the location and the type of activity.

loans.use: to buy more inventory items for the eatery to provide more to locals and increase her income

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy clothing and footwear

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
Rosemary has been in dairy farming for the last six years and she is doing so well.  She is married and a mother of three children ages 18, 16 and 13 years respectively.

She has applied for a loan of KES 40,000 which she will use to buy dairy feeds and repair the dairy shelter.  This is her third loan after she serviced her previous loan successfully.

Rosemary will use the anticipated income to pay school fees for her children.  She hopes to grow her business and be financially stable.

loans.use: To buy dairy feeds and repair the dairy pen

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for steel bars, timber and glue

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a mobile phone and a solar charging set

loans.name: Leik Kan Village

texts.en:
Located in Central Myanmar’s Magway Township, this community currently has 65 village customers, including six Community Based Organization (CBO) committee members who help to lead the loan program in the area. In this village, farmers will cultivate seven acres on average. Most villagers are Buddhists and will save money to celebrate cultural ceremonies and offer provisions to monks. Although there are three wells to supply water to the village, two of the wells have broken engines, so only one is working well enough to consistently supply fresh water.

A new loan would enable this community to pay for labor fees. Due to the lack of job opportunities in the village, many young people are migrating to other cities. As a result, there are not many people who are able to work on the farms, and the cost of labor has increased to $4 for one day. Those who own many acres need to hire labor to weed at least twice per season. To supplement crop income, villagers will raise livestock such as goats, work on government-sponsored road construction projects, and collect green gram from neighboring cities.

Pictured above are the committee members from the Leik Kan Village CBO: U Soe, Daw Shwe, Daw Mar, U Kyaw, U Phel, and Daw Than. Included in the photo (third from the right) is U Soe, who is 38-years-old and the father of two small children. The new loan would help him to pay for laborers to weed his farm to protect his crops. He expects to spend about $150 in labor fees this farming season.

loans.use: to help 65 villagers hire laborers to help with weeding

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy spare motor parts

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy tomatoes and onions for resale

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en: Ruth is a single mother of five children, two of whom go to school. She has a business selling fruit and has been in this business for fifteen years. She has applied for a loan of 500,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT - SACCO to buy more baskets of oranges and mangoes, paw paws and pineapples. She generates additional income from frying and selling samosas and pancakes. She works at the market seven days a week, every week. Her main business challenges include seasonality and thieves. She aspires to become a wholesaler and to buy a plot of land to build her own house. She resides in a rented house where the family has access to electricity but not piped water. Her main monthly expenses are rent and school fees.

loans.use: To buy paw paws, pineapples, mangoes and oranges

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a mobile phone and a solar charging set so that he may provide vital farming information to his community.

loans.name: Solomon

texts.en:
Solomon, a husband and father of seven children, is a mixed small-scale farmer based in the remote village of Kona Mbaya, Kitale. He has been practicing agribusiness for the past nine years and has never looked back. For a living, Solomon sells milk and food products from his farm into the local market. He makes extra money with a business running the only diesel posho mill in his village since there is no electricity connection. He enjoys seeing clients coming back for more of his products and he really feels satisfied.

Although Solomon has been making profits through farming, he has always wanted to do poultry farming. The main challenge he has encountered is a lack of funds to get his business off the ground. Solomon is seeking a loan to buy quality breeds of poultry. Poultry farming is a very profitable business venture in Kitale and is a business that can be done on a part-time basis to earn extra income. Solomon does not worry too much about competition because the market for poultry products is good - chicken is a popular meal for many people and this can be seen if you visit any fast food joint. With this loan, Solomon is confident that his income will increase and this will allow a permanent change in his life. He plans to buy different breeds of broilers and layers and will be selling eggs and meat to the local market and other major markets in Kenya. He also plans to start breeding, which will help increase the number of poultry on his farm. Other than profits from selling eggs, poultry feathers, and poultry meat, Solomon will also benefit from using the poultry manure, which is an excellent source of nutrients for his farm. Through this loan, he will assure his large family of a secure future and improved living conditions.

loans.use: To start poultry farming

loans.name: Justine

texts.en:
Justine is married and has two children, both of whom go to school. She also takes care of an additional family member, her mother.  Justine has a business selling used shoes and has been in this business for five years.

Justine has applied for a loan of 200,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT - SACCO to buy more shoes. She doesn’t have any other income generating activities. Justine works in her shop seven days out of every week. Her major business challenges include thieves and seasonality. She is aspires to import used shoes and also to become a wholesaler. Justine resides in a rented house and her family has access to electricity, but not to piped water.  Her monthly expenses include school fees and rent.

loans.use: To buy a bale of used shoes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a mobile phone and a solar charging set so that he may provide vital farming information to his community.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a mobile phone and a solar charging set so that he may provide vital farming information to his community.

loans.name: Aidah

texts.en: Aidah is married with two children, only one of whom goes to school. She also takes care of additional family members (sister.) She has a business selling green bananas and has been in this business for two years. She works seven days a week. She has applied for a loan of 100,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT - SACCO to buy more bunches and bags of green bananas. Her major business challenges include seasonality and defaulters. She is aspiring to go to villages for green bananas and also to become a wholeseller. She resides in a rented house and the family has access to electricity and not to piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and rent.

loans.use: to buy bunches of green bananas.

loans.name: Amina

texts.en: Amina is married with six children and all her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members (grandchildren.) She has a business of selling fresh fruits and vegetables at the market. She has been in this business for 14 years. She has applied for a loan of 200,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more bags of fresh cow peas, beans, cabbage, carrots, and onions. She generates additional income from selling piped water.  She works at the market six days a week and sells on a retail basis. Her major business challenges include seasonality and perishability of her products. She lives in her own house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her major expenses includes school fees and food.

loans.use: to buy fresh beans, peas, onions, and cabbage.

loans.name: Ilona

texts.en:
Ilona is a 34-year-old woman, from Senaki district. She is a mother of four school-aged children and her family's only source of income is Ilona's husband's job. He works at the conduit and generates 200 GEL approximately. The family gets social assistance from the local government for its poor living condition. The income is really hardly enough to meet even basic needs. Ilona requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for her trading business startup but without any success. Her loan request was rejected each time because the creditors did not find the existing family income to be sufficient to approve the loan.

According to Credo estimations, the family belongs to the vulnerable poor category. Ilona has requested a Credo loan for the start-up of a trading business. Her loan request was approved in the frames of a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provisions of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions for the country's rural poor, who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. Ilona will purchase stock of clothing and other home products and start local trading. Ilona and her husband will be able to create better living conditions for their children and themselves.

loans.use: to start a trading business in order to tackle financial difficulties.

loans.name: Maa Kshetrapal Shg Group

texts.en: Basanti is a 30-year-old woman married to a farmer in a small village of Sonepur in Odisha, India. The couple has three children who are in school. Basanti lives with her children and, together with her husband, takes care of all the household expenses. In order to help with all the family expenses, Basanti has been involved in doing paddy cultivation and selling it to the distributors for the past six years. She supplies her paddy and rice to the rice dealers in the nearby market. In order to strengthen the business and respond to client demand, Basanti, together with the group Maa Kshetrapal SHG, is requesting a loan from Peoples Forum for purchasing fertilizers, pesticides, and seeds, and to cover the operational costs. Their goal is to increase their business activity.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, pesticides, and seeds, and to cover their operational costs for paddy cultivation.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is a 51-year-old lady who is married and blessed with two adult children, ages 26 and 20. She runs a tailoring business and also a secondary poultry business which is able to give her an income of about 25,000 Kenya shilling every month. Her husband is an electrician and also brings in more income from his skills.

She has applied for a second loan which she plans to use to top up on paying the education fees for her children's university education. She hopes her business does well so that she is able to repay the loan and expand her business.

In the future, she would like to have a stable business.

loans.use: to pay for school fees.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a mobile phone and a solar charging set, so that she may provide vital farming information to her community.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a mobile phone and a solar charging set so that he may provide vital farming information to his community.

loans.name: Kuzhul Shg - Velur Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Selvi is a leader of the “Kuzhul” Self-Help Group (holding a board with SHG name) with 14 other women, to which PAT, the local NGO, has been giving loans to improve their livelihoods. Selvi lives in a small hamlet in the rural area of Velur in Tanjore District, Tamil Nadu. She is married and her husband is a farmer. They have two children. They live in a house made of thatched roof.

India accounts for six lakh (600,000) deaths every year caused by acute lower respiratory infections. This is the leading causes of disease and mortality, which are the offspring of indoor pollution and lung congestion caused by the use of traditional stoves emitting smoke. A majority of villagers usually cook on the earthen stove or a three-brick earthen burner, which over a period of time is responsible for lung disease and blurred vision. 

Hence, Selvi and her group members are looking forward to this loan to purchase a smokeless stove that can be used in their kitchen and help them breathe clean air.

loans.use: to purchase a smokeless stove

loans.name: Maa Brundabati Shg Group

texts.en:
The responsible Maa Brundabati Self Help Group is made up of 10 members. The members of the group are all women from the district of Sonepur in Odisha, India. All the group members are involved in doing different kinds of activities. 

One of them is Sapura, who was selected as their president. The lady standing with her raised hand is Sapura. Sapura is 29 years old and lives with her husband and her two children. She is engaged in the activity of making plates, bowls, spoons and other utensils from brass, and then sells them in the nearby market. These plates are used for different purposes, mainly for serving food, and sometimes are used while performing rituals. She makes different types and sizes of plates and bowls, depending upon the demands of her customers. Sapura has a plan to expand her business by producing greater quantities of her products, for which she needs machinery with which she can make the plates more frequently and quickly. She also needs raw materials like coal, brass, a furnace, etc. She has a very good relationship with her customers because she completes their orders on time. Sapura and her group have requested this loan for expanding their businesses.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials like coal, brass, a furnace, etc. for her utensil-making business.

loans.name: Thirowpathiyamman 1 Shg - Ganapathiagraharam Group

texts.en:
Kasturi is the featured borrower of “Thirowpathiyamman 1” Self Help group, which includes nine other members from the same locality of Ganapathiagraharam village in Tamil Nadu. Kasturi is 33 years old and her husband is a farmer. They have two children and live in their own house. They also own some cultivatable land in their village. The group has been receiving loans from “PAT” for the last three years for the cultivation of paddy, cotton seeds etc. 

Now Kasturi and her group members are each seeking a loan to buy a smokeless stove that is produced by Grameen Infra. The stove costs INR 1,400 each. This will help all the borrowers have a good environment in their home surroundings.

loans.use: to buy a smokeless stove

loans.name: Louange (1) Group

texts.en:
André is a micro-entrepreneur in Brazzaville, Republic of Congo. He owns a small butcher shop and sandal stand. Only 19 years old, André joined a community bank group with HOPE Congo last year and hopes to start his second loan cycle by taking out a loan of 250,000 XAF. With this money he plans to purchase additional meats to sell such has fish, chicken and tripe. André hopes to be able to grow his business until it flourishes and provides a stable income. One day André dreams of being able to fully support himself and lead a balanced life.

André loves the business practice of saving, and every two days he makes sure to put a little aside from his sales in order to help achieve his dreams.

loans.use: to purchase additional meats to sell such has fish, chicken and tripe.

loans.name: Developpement (2) Group

texts.en:
Arland is the father of three children and a micro-entrepreneur in Brazzaville, the Republic of Congo. For the last eight years, Arland has sold salted fish and drinks in the market and at home. In order to increase his profits and expand his business, Arland joined HOPE Congo last year and is currently on his third loan cycle. A member of the community bank group Developpement (2), Arland leads a small subgroup of seven other micro-entrepreneurs in Brazzaville. He would like to take out a loan of 350,000 CFA to purchase additional imported fish and drinks to sell.

Eventually Arland dreams of expanding his businesses to also owning and renting out vehicles like taxis, which are an extremely popular mode of transport in Brazzaville. He hopes to keeps supporting his family so that his children will be well off, and eventually have their own piece of land to live on.

loans.use: to purchase additional imported fish and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Christ Vivant 3 (1) Group

texts.en:
Rancia runs a used clothing business in Brazzaville, Republic of Congo, and is a member of the community bank group CHRIST VIVANT 3 (1).  As the mother of five school-aged children, Rancia has her hands full supporting her family. For the last 12 years, Rancia has been running her used clothing business and dreams of one day being able to advance from selling individual pieces of clothing to selling in bulk. 

As the leader of a subgroup of 10 other micro-entrepreneurs in CHRIST VIVANT 3 (2), Rancia is currently on her third loan cycle with HOPE Congo. She would like to take out a loan of 350,000 AXF to purchase additional bundles of clothing to sell. Rancia dreams of continuing to take care of her family’s needs as her business expands.

loans.use: to purchase additional bundles of clothing to sell.

loans.name: Biswa Maa Lachhama Shg Group

texts.en:
Kanak is engaged in the activity of decorating and making tent houses for events like marriages and other Hindu rituals. She has tents, a few musical instruments and speakers, which she installs wherever the events are performed. She has three years of experience in this activity. Kanak lives with her parents-in-laws and one child. She is a responsible 25-year-old leader of the loan group named Biswa Maa Lachhama Self Help Group, and lives in a small village in Odisha, India. 

Biswa Maa Lachhama Self Help Group has 11 members, all women, living in the same neighborhood but involved in various types of activities. She, along with her group members, has requested a loan of 143,000 Indian Rupees (INR). She will use her portion to purchase new, upgraded musical instruments and bamboo to install in her tent house and to hire a few more laborers for help. She wants to save some money for her family's better future and for her child's education.

loans.use: to buy new upgraded musical instruments and bamboo for installing in her tent house.

loans.name: Bindusindhu Shg Group

texts.en:
In 2013, nine women from a village stepped out and decided to build a secure future for their families. They formed a group named Bindusindhu Self Help Group. The members of Bindusindhu Self Help Group are all women from the district of Sonepur in Odisha, India. 

One of them is Ura, who was selected as their president. The lady standing with her raised hand is Ura. Ura is 38 years old and is staying separately from her husband due to some personal reasons. She has two children and both are living with her. Ura got the idea of doing vegetable cultivation from her group. She wants to educate her children, so she started growing vegetables a few years back. This helped her in managing her household necessities. Initially, she started with growing only a few vegetables like potatoes, tomatoes and onions, but later on she grew bitter gourds, snake gourds, cucumbers, lady fingers and brinjal (eggplant). She has a very good relationship with her customers, as she sells fresh vegetables to them. Now she has a new idea to purchase some more land for cultivation so that she can grow more vegetables on a large scale, for which she has requested a loan to purchase small plants, seeds, pesticides and fertilizers.

loans.use: to purchase small plants, seeds, pesticides and fertilizers for her vegetable growing business.

loans.name: Rock Of Ages Group

texts.en:
The group known as Rock of Ages 1 is made up of seven people who live in the same neighborhood. They sell  groceries, plantains, materials, wigs, kenkey (cook corn paste), fish, rice, oil, African wax prints and sachet water.

The featured borrower of the group, Stella, is 43. She was able to attend school to the primary level. She is married and the mother of four children. Three of them are enrolled in school and one was born in 2014. 

Stella lives with her children and husband, and she has been making good income from her business. In order to cover her various household expenses, Stella sells plantains through the distribution system and also on foot. Stella has been in this business for eight years and buys plantains from the farmers in Ghana. In order to cater to the demand of her ever-growing number of clients and earn more profit, Stella, together with the other members of the group known as Rock of Ages 1, is asking for her first loan from ID Ghana.

loans.use: to buy plantains from the farmers in Ghana.

loans.name: Thirowpathiyamman-2 Shg-Ganapathiagraharam Group

texts.en:
Given its abundance, firewood is a common domestic fuel in India, especially in rural households. Boopathy, who hails from Ganapathiagraharam in Tamil Nadu, cooks food using a makeshift cook stove that runs on firewood. Many women living in her neighborhood are dependent on similar cook stoves and firewood. 

Unfortunately, these women are putting themselves at the brink of contracting fatal lung diseases such as lung cancer, pneumonia, bronchitis, etc., as they inhale a high volume of smoke emanating from burning firewood every day.         

Boopathy has teamed up with four women to purchase low-smoke cook stoves available in the market. All these women earn a living by small livelihood activities. Their earnings are not sufficient to purchase the smokeless stoves. 

This loan will help them breathe safer air while preparing food for their families.

loans.use: to purchase low-smoke cook stoves

loans.name: Amman Shg-Keelapalur Group

texts.en:
Janaki is the leader of the Amman Self-Help Group, which is managed by the local NGO, People Action for Transformation (PAT), in Tamil Nadu, India.   

Janaki hails from Keelapalur village. She lives in her own house with her two children and husband. Her husband is a small, marginal farmer who works on daily wages.

Janaki wants to purchase a smokeless stove because it uses less wood and hardly emits any smoke. This means less carbon dioxide and it saves time and labor. The traditional stove emits a lot of smoke, and it leads to air pollution, deforestation etc.

The other members of the group are requesting a loan to purchase smokeless stoves to have a healthier life.

loans.use: to buy a smokeless stove

loans.name: Louange (2) Group

texts.en:
François is a single father of seven children in Brazzaville, Republic of Congo. He runs his own business selling coal and kindling. Soon after he started his business, François learned about HOPE Congo and joined the community bank group, LOUANGE (2). François is the leader of a sub-group of 11 other micro-entrepreneurs in Brazzaville, and he would like to take out his second loan with HOPE Congo. With 250,000 XAF, François will be able to purchase additional bags of coal and kindling in bulk to sell in small bundles.

While it can be difficult to transport his goods from the forest to the market to sell, François keeps ahead of the competition by working hard to have a constant supply of stock. François has big dreams for the future, and hopes to one day become a supplier of wood and coal in bulk. He dreams of continuing to support his family in the future so that they can prosper.

loans.use: to purchase additional bags of coal and kindling.

loans.name: Maa Dasamati Shg Group

texts.en:
Shanti is 37 years old and married. She lives in a house made of mud, with her husband and two children, in a rural village in the Sonepur district in Odisha, India. She and her husband earn a living by farming rice and vegetables that they sell in the market. Having been in this business for 10 years, she manages to earn about 5,000 INR per month and can save about 2,000 INR each month for future needs. 

This is a group loan for Maa Dasamati Self Help Group, which consists of eight women. The members of this group are engaged in different kinds of activities.
